issues.description: The problem statement and the template expect a no-argument Rideable.messageOnRide() that returns a string like "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]" (see UML and the example loop in Main which calls r.messageOnRide()). The solution repository, however, defines Rideable.messageOnRide(String equipment) (adds a String parameter) and implements it in Pig and Seal to include the equipment (e.g. "Riding on Pig Doodle with saddle"). This parameter mismatch prevents students from implementing the interface as specified in the exercise and will make the template Main and any tests that call messageOnRide() without arguments incompatible with the solution code.

The problem statement's UML and textual description define Rideable.messageOnRide() as a no-argument method returning a String (and the provided Main() code calls r.messageOnRide() with no argument). In the solution repository, the Rideable interface and its implementations (Pig, Seal) define messageOnRide(String equipment) — i.e., the same conceptual operation has a different method signature (an extra parameter named 'equipment') in the solution. This mismatch breaks the API students are asked to implement/use (the name is the same but the signature differs) and will cause confusion: students following the problem/template will implement/call a no-arg messageOnRide(), while the solution expects a one-arg variant that changes the returned string format.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method signature across artifacts. Either (A) change the solution to match the problem/template by making Rideable.messageOnRide() a no-argument method (String messageOnRide()) and update Pig and Seal implementations to return "Riding on [AnimalType] [name]" (no equipment), or (B) update the problem statement and template (UML and example calls in Main) to declare and use messageOnRide(String equipment) and document the equipment parameter. Option A is recommended so the solution follows the exercise specification.
